Average. I did not really find anything special about this church. There were some nice sculptures on the outside and a very nice organ and pulpit on the inside. Entrance is free. I would visit this church if I wanted to go and pray and spend some time in the Lord's presence. If you want to see a really great church with sites to behold go to the Church of Our Savior on Spilled Blood.
A St. Petersburg landmark. We never went into this cathedral but used it as a constant landmark because it can be seen from all over the city.

To heavy, too un-russian. The luxurius and heavy construction of St Isaac's cathedral is an impresive monument of litle artistic value. It was made to impress the foreign dignitaries (and today tourists) than to be the church of the Russian Orthodoxy. There are other places of greater intersts in the city

St. Isaac's Cathedral - St. Petersburg. We were not scheduled to go inside St. Isaac's Cathedral. We were only scheduled to stop for pictures of the outside. On the second day we were in St. Petersburg, our tour guide, Mariana, asked us if we would like to go inside. We were able to spend about 20 minutes in this wonderful building. The interior was more striking than the outside and I'm glad we were able to enjoy it, if only for a few minutes. We used Ulko Tours while we were in St. Petersburg, and our guide, Mariana, knew all about the art work and the history of St. Isaac's. I'm so glad she gave us the option of going inside. I loved the mosaics. They were stunning and looked as if they were paintings. The stained glass was also wonderful. "St. Isaac's is the fourth largest domed cathedral of its type in the world after St. Peter's in Rome, St. Paul's in London and Santa Maria dei Fiori in Florence." I had been iside the other three cathedrals and was glad to check St. Isaac's off my list.
Magnificent architecture and interior. Beautiful Cathedral inside and out with a lot of history. It can get crowded and noisy at times which make the experience less serene.Definitely worth a visit.

St. Isaac's Cathedral. St. Isaac's Cathedral is one of the great churches of the world. It is the fourth largest domed cathedral in the world. It is adorned both inside and oujt with sculptures and reliefs. The mosaics inside are particularly noteworthy and the cathedral can hold up to 14,000 people.

it wasn't just "another bloody church!". I didn't think I'd want to see ABC -- another bloody church, but am glad I toured St Isaac's. I first climbed the 5-7 minutes of steps to the colonnade (top of the domes) for panoramic views of St Petersburg. Then I toured the museum/cathedral, which is new and lovely inside. On the Sat afternoon I was there, a Russian Orthodox service was being held in one corner of the church. I used my shawl to cover my head and joined the local parishioners for part of the service, so in the end, it wasn't just ABC.

Beautiful Church. We enjoyed this church very much. It was large and we were able to walk around without the usual crowds. The doors on the chuch are beautifully cast, so take some time to enjoy them.
The climb is worth it. 262 steps to the dome but well worth it as you get a great view over the city. The best view in St Petersburg

It's really big. A huge Renaissance-style 19th century centrally planned cathedral with neoclassical mosaics of religious subjects, models of how the enormous columns were installed, souvenir stands, and a multitude of historical displays. As everyone notes, the gold dome is visible from all over the city.

A mass at the cathedral. The building itself is worth seeing. We attended the 6 pm mass/service (standing for 1.5 hour). it is an interesting cultural experience for someone from a Catholic background. Lots of nice songs.
Amazing. This is a beautifully restored cathedral. Neglected under the Soviets, it is wonderful today. I especially liked learning about the art that has been restored.
Brilliant views from the Colonnade. Good museum inside - disapoined we had to pay for both the museum and the colonnade separately. Fab views from the top.
awesome. This was one of the most beautiful sites we have ever visited. The mosaics are really unbelievable. It is so colorful and interesting.
Nice view. Climb to the top, especially in the summer when it's open until late night. The views are worth it, and the building itself is magnificent in its glory and size.

Great view. I only had time to go up to the viewing area at the top but it was great even to do that. Such a view. There aren't that many steps really and the climb is worth it. I went in the evening and with the beginnings of a red sky it was great to see St Petersburg in all its glory.
St Isaacs Cathedral. What a magnificent cathedral to walk to from the park side. the view from the top is just magnificent. a lot of stairs - 161 - but worth it.

A beautiful church. We visited St. Isaac's Cathedral as part of a two day visit to St. Petersburg. Although not as spectacular as the Church of the Blood, it is a beautiful church and well worth a visit. Make sure that you have a guide to enhance your trip.
nice view. the cathedral was amazing. I would definitly buy combined ticket to go to tower also. Nice views of Saint Petersburg.

Imposing!. Orthodox church designed by French architect Au. Montferrand, It is imposing at 101 meters high. Doors are made of wood. With its ginormous size, it is opened by special hydraulics. All images are in mosaic except for one stained glass image of Jesus. There is a gift shop inside that sells really interesting pieces of jewelries in amber.Tips: It has a really lovely park in front and best place for leisurely walk.

Huge Golden Dome. This is an impressive structure, seen by it's gleaming golden dome and huge red columns outside. Inside, it is highly decorated and beautiful. There is a wooden construction model showing how the building was built. Some of the exterior columns still show damage from German shelling during WWII.

Stunning. A very tall church with golden 'kupola' next to the Admiralty on the Neva river is absolutely stunning. Entry has a fee, but you can climb up to the terrance for the beautiful views of the area.

Amazing cathedral in St.Petes....be strong & fit to climb..... St. Isaac's Cathedral was originally the city's main church and the largest cathedral in Russia and definitely one of the most impressive landmarks of the Russian Imperial capital. The interiors marble, woodworks, scale of the place will impress any visitors. The cathedral's facades are adorned with sculptures and huge granite columns (made of single pieces of red granite), while the interior is adorned with incredibly detailed mosaic icons, paintings and columns. A large, brightly colored stained glass window of the "Resurrected Christ" is prominently displayed inside the main altar. You should buy entrance tickets just inside the right-hand door in the southern facade. The highlight of the visit is the 300 steps climb up to the cathedral's colonnade, and be rewarded by the magnificent views over the city.
majestic. Huge space inside-very high & ornate.Admission 250 roublesPay another 150 roubles to climb 260 steps to colonnade for magnificent city views

Mosaic artwork is incredible - the whole place is a masterpiece.. We stood and gazed at every corner - the headphones you can rent are worth it, to hear the history and descriptions. Amazing place not to be missed.

Look for the dove!. Another magnificent church to see! The gold was everywhere, large marble and semi precious (lapis) pillars to round out the beautiful large church. The art work is just breathtaking and it's so hard to take it all in at one time. The dome is amazing and look for the dove in the middle!

Cannot miss this one. This is the largest orthodox church in the City. The Iconastas is amazing, lots of detail & gold leaf and precious stones. The dome (topped with a cupola) is huge and lots of relief work on the inside. The outer is covered in gold and can be seen from various places in the city. The work is impressive, quite how the huge marble pillars were erected is amazing!

Loved it. St. Isaacs allows you to climb to the top of the chuch and get 360-degree views of the city. What is great, is that the climb is open at least 18-20 hours a day (we went up at 10pm after dinner), and since the latitude is so high, it is light even that late at night.

Magnificent. St. Petersburg largest Cathedral, St. Isaac's gleams in history with it's huge gold plated dome that took over 500,000 workers to complete. Still riddled with bullets holes from world war II this national treasure should be on your must see list.

Great view from the top. Our hotel was located right next door, we even had a view on the cathedral from our windows, so it was obvious that one of the first sights we visited in SPB was the St. Isaac's Cathedral. We were lucky as there was no que at the ticket office and within 5 minutes we were on the top at the duom and enjoyed the spectaculat view of the city. Simply great. The onyl minus is the monoton voice of a recorded Russian guide that gives you info about what you can see in the different directions... a bit annoying some little info pic or tableaux would be more sufficient, so everybody could enjoy the view without in "silence".

Beautiful. I recommend purchasing the ticket to climb to the top. Amazing views of St. Petersburg. The inside is beyond words... floor to ceiling murals depicting scenes from the Bible. It's a must see!
St Isaacs Cathedral. Beautiful Cathedral! We spent about an hour looking at the Icons and its one of the most beautiful churches we have been to.

St. Issac. St. Isaac looks great from outside, but I was a bit disappointed as somehow I was expecting to see more inside. There is an observation deck, but I didn’t have a power to climb those steps…
Climb the steps to see St Petersburg. Climbing the steps to the St Isaac's colonnade is well worth the effort. Even on a day with rain and wind we had an excellent view over the city.

I'm Impressed!. St Isaac's was built between 1818-1858. Its facade is adorned with sculptures and massive granite columns. Inside the Church are mosaic icons, paintings and columns made of malachite and lapis lazuli. The centerpiece of the altar is a stained glass depicting the resurrection of Jesus Christ. There is a sign that says no photo or video allowed but if you are with an organized tour you have to pay a fee to the guide in order to take photos inside. Don't forget to go up the stairs to get a good view of the area. There is is also a monument of Nicholas I in the square.

Great neoclassical cathedral with observation deck. Marvelous church all covered with mosaics, gold and precious stones inside. Separate ticket is required to climb up the wide stairs to the top of the cupola for overview of the city.
Great city view!. The interior of the cathedral is interesting, but the view fromthe top is the highlight - well worth the climb!
Climb to the colony. and enjoy brilliant view! You have to go around 200 stairs up.. but, if you dont like the move, they are building the lift already.
Mosaics anyone. This place is like one big mosaic. Everything was done piece by piece. From the tile artwork to the beautifully designed floors and doors. Get your cameras ready!
Huge and impressive. Definitely worth a visit. Didn't climb to balcony but it seemed like a great view.
Wonderful History. A beautiful place to learn about the religious culture of historical Russia in a eye popping display of beauty. Wish I'd had the time to climb the tower. It looked like fun.
The most fantastic building in St Petersburg. This is absolutely the most impressive church I have seen outside of Rome (St Peter's Basilica) .

Extraordinary size pillars support the church.. I loved the outer appearance of St Isaaca Cathedral as it was unusual in the city of churches and domes. The gigantic pillars were visible from a distance & invited you in to see the splendours of the inside. Mosaics, lapis lazuli and other semi precious stones.Very interesting model showing the building and plans for the structure of it.
Icons of Gold and jewels.. If you love art then add this in.The collection and the feel of orthodox Russia is residual here.

Wonderful. Had a view of this from the Angelterre Hotel where we stayed.
We didnt go inside but the view from on top was great.
We were there during their White Nights and it was strange seeing people sightseeing at 11.45pm in the sunshine.

Beautiful outside - dark and brooding inside. As an active place of worship, we were restricted as to where we could go inside the cathedral. But I really appreciated that it was not simply a museum - we got a good sense of the importance of Russian Orthodox worship, the use of icons, and the differences in this church versus ones in Europe. Outside, the building is stunning in blue and white - like a finely decorated cake with golden domes. Try to bring a head covering (i.e. scarf) for ladies, no hat for men, and conservative dress overall.
Another gem. Definitively amazing, i have a picture taken up high - just a sea of old roofs - so gorgeous and inspiring :)

Great mosaics and paintings but that is it, spend an hour if it is raining. Oner Ayan. Central location, has very nice collection of Russian Orthodox religious art, but limited in number. Go to Russian Museum or Savior church if you don't have much time. Oner Ayan
From outside to inside. From outside you can see how the arcitecture saw grandiose!!!!It is a beauty of decor and gold qualities of enjoyment
Extaordinary. Amazing structure with magnificent marble pillars outside, and quite exceptional art and mosaics inside!

Most "European" attraction I saw while in Russia. Nice cathedral, but ranks average when compared to other churches with Western European decor inside. Admission to get in, entrance to colonade separate, both are photo-worthy. Stairwell for the Colonade is approx 250 steps, stairwell is wide enough but there are a couple narrow doorways on the way to the top. The railings at the top are quite low, I'm 5'6" and the railings did not reach my waist so don't lean too far.
Top Notch. After a while, you run out of superlatives for all the incredible places in St. Petersburg, but St. Isaacs is still on the Must See list.

Comparable to other grand cathedrals in Europe. Similar in grandeur to St Peters and St Pauls, however it does reveal a dark side of Russia. During the height of Communism it was actually designated as a museum of atheism, as the country was and still is for the most part, athiest in their religious views. You just have to keep things in perspective as it is a beautful facility. We understand that it is now officially again a Russian Orthodox church, but worship is still considered something that might inhibit you in their society.

Great view of the city!. Most liked the view of the city from the cathedral roof, but cathedral itself also worth visiting. They offer free 30 minutes guided tours, which are great if you understand russian. The models of previous three cathedral buildings, some frescs which turned in mosaic version, malachite and lazurite columns are very different from all previously seen churches.
Beautifully restored. The inside is truly a Church although also a museum...like many Churches in Russia.
Massive place. Very impressive place and do not miss the climb to the dome. Tends to be a bit crowded but it is well worth a visit.
Very near to our accomodation. We had a view of St Isaacs and the night time view is terrific. The building is very impressive. There is a charge but one of the sites worth visiting.
Architectural Marvel. Every kind of stone used to build this huge cathedral.Very impressive

Left me cold. The massive gold dome was made using a technique involving mercury. Tragically, this led to many, many deaths. I found it hard to be impressed after being told this and it just all felt a bit wrong.
stunning. This is the best view of St. Petersburg, so don't miss going up to the dome. It's a separate cost, but it's worth it. The church is extraordinary and iconic.
It is worth climbing up. It'll cost you 150 rubles and 262 steps but the view is spectacular. If you do it when it's hot, remember your water bottle!
A very nice church, with a very special view. Our guide took our kids to the cupola, where they had a grand view of the city
Beautiful. This cathedral is worth a visit. It has a combination of majesty, mosaics and paintings.
And yet another wonderful church. The domes remind me of St Basil's in Moscow. Rather brilliantly beautiful.

A Glided Black Capitol. Absolutely gorgeous. The cathedral is made of black stone with a single huge golden dome surrounded by intricate granite statues representing angels. The interior is full of amazing examples of art such as mosaics which are pictures made up of thousands of tiny multicoloured stones and icons, which are oil paintings on the interior walls of the Cathedral. A guide will be invaluable here in explaining the mosaics, statues, icons and the significance of their placement. The inside of the cathedral simply leaves you awestruck. The inside of the hollow dome contains ten incredibly detailed golden statues in a circle and the ceilings are a multitude of paintings, ranging from a few inches to several meters in length and width. The sheer amount of gold used in decorating walls , ceilings, pillars and sculptures enhances the cathedral's magnificence...
Gilded triumph. Vast cathedral, stunning marble interior and golden dome, spectacular views from gallery of dome.
Worth the visit. It´s located in the main Prospekt in St. Petersburg. Even you son´t want, you will see it. So, why not check it out?
Interesting. Not as unbelieveable as Spilled Blood but very good. Interesting to see the tombs of Russian Czars.

NIce one. We enjoyed our time .St. Isaac's Cathedral is the largest cathedral in St. Petersburg. It was the largest church in Russia when it was built (101.5 meters high), and is still the third largest domed cathedral in the world. For visitors willing to climb 300 steps, it provides a spectacular view of St. Petersburg.

Beautiful views from the top, fabulous interior. You pay separately to go up to the top, 262 steps, and go inside. Well worth doing both. The views of the city from the top are superb, and the interior of the cathedral is exquisite.

2 Day St. Petersburg Experience. This cathedral is one of the most beautiful places of worship I have seen. It rivals the mosques of Istanbul. Another place that is not to be missed in St. Petersburg.
Majestic looking. We loved this cathedral we did the climb to the top which gave us the most breathtaking views. The cost was well worth it for the stunning views of the city.
What were the masses doing. St Petersburg is a place where all the great monuments and structures around the world can be experienced in like at the one location
Must see. Great interior, and pictures are allowed. Be sure and check the open times before you plan your trip.
Very Spiritual. All of the paintings and statues touched my heart. They were just awesome.

A must. Breath taking views at the top, spent a full half an hour just taking in the view. A slight trek, but bearable. Inside of the Cathedral is also a stunner. Would gladly pay the price to visit again.

impressive dome. Would have enjoyed a little more time here. The dome is most impressive, so if you are a bit rushed, as we were, take a quick look, and keep in mind that the Russians camouflaged the entire dome during the Nazi invasion to protect it from bombs--and it worked!

This is a grandiose Architectural work of Russia. St. Isaac's Cathedral is really a grandiose architectural work of Russia as precious Cultural Property from the 19th Century. It was admiration for the great Conservation of Russia about this historical monument and left people in general and Russian in particular a magnificent Cultural heritage value. It really made me amazed and I will never forget this interesting trip.
St. Isaac. Still another incredible cathedral with more history that you could imagine. A must see.

breathtaking views. inside of it can be omitted, but if you are a history buff, it is well worth it. it is a bit of a journey, up to the dome, but well worth the shortage of breath after having climbed the equivalent of 18 storey high building through the stairs, you get an amazing view of the city
Loved the view. We didn't get to see the inside of the Cathedral. However, we walked the steps up to the top of the Colonnade and got a great view of the city.

St Isaac Cathedral - Main church in St Petersburg. Just big, dark, in comparison to all the other lovely light, airy byzantine churches in the city.
Probably more important historically than artistically. Religiously, I think it is only used from time to time as a house or worship.

Climb the stairs for the view. The inside and outside of this cathedral are worth seeing. All the marble for the pillars was transported from Finland to Russia. The doors and interior are also ornate.
Climb the 253 stairs to the top for a view over the city - worth the energy it takes.

One of the top six sights in St Petersburg. Built in 1858 (it took 40 years to construct) it is the fourth largest dome in the world (I understand) and is a sight to behold. A museum during communist rule it is used for worship services now. Giant solid granite columns where miraculous to put up. The stained glass window of the Resurrection of Christ is beautiful. Will take less than one hour to see.
interesting huge church. Another over the top Cathedral, worth seeing because of the size and the choir that sings in the morning
Isaac's a Must See. Make sure your tour takes you inside and not just a drive-by. This is a huge cathdedral and the inside ceilings reminds one of St. Peters in Rome.
Wonderful ceilings and decorations. Another spectacular building in ST P. Not my top list of attractions, but can be visited for half an hour en route to other places

Make sure not to miss the "museum". The view of St. Petersburg from above is worth the 262 (shallow) steps it takes to reach the collonade. But for us the cathedral itself (called "the museum" at the ticket booth) was the highlight. The history is fascinating and described on displays around the perimeter -- from a church to an anti-religion museum in early Soviet times to the museum/cathedral of today.There are several ticket booths at street level on the side, in addition to the booth at entrance level. It is worth it to seek them out and avoid the lines at the main ticket booth. In retrospect, this is what the many announcements in Russian only must have been trying to tell us.
The best view at sunset. Open until late we went up the tower at 11pm to see the sun set and the views were majestic
A beautifull church not be missed during your visit. try to take the tour of the cathedral, it's worth it as gives lots of information you otherwise wouldnt notice/know

Simply beautiful. Really beautiful place full of plenty of information and displays about the history of the site. A must visit for any visit to Saint Petersburg. Pay the money and take the stairs up to the dome, best part of the place and the best view anywhere of the whole city

Breathtaking in more ways than one!. Imposing and oustanding from the exterior and just as impressive from the inside. If you want to go up the colonnade (262 steps) make sure you buy tickets for both at the entrance as they are sold separately

The First Stunning Dome You See. This wonderful church with it's golden dome is seen on the skyline from allover St. P. The decor is gorgeous and the engineering marvel of it's construction is fascinating. Make the climb for the view, if you have young legs!
Another great cathedral. Beautiful, worth going up the collonade for the views of the city.
Spectacular. Another "must-see" in St Petersburg. Incredible art and architecture, truly wonderful.
Great inside and out. The most European of the churches, the decor inside is amazing, and it is worth the 262 step climb to get the highest views of SPB
Definitely do the climb. The climb gives you the panoramic views of the city. The museum/ church interiors are worth spending time and arrive early. Both activities require separate tickets.

La piece de resistance!. By far the most interesting and enjoyable of all of the cathedrals that we visited. Again it was Russian Orthodox with ahistory that would make you cry, - how it was used during the siege of Leningrad,(St Petersburg) from 1941 to 1944 and its use by the Soviets after the war. But how well it has been refurbished would make you shout for joy. It is truly a beautiful building inside and out.
Climb the done for the best city views. Great mosaics, paintings and simply a majestic cathederal
St Isaacs. Spectacular. Gorgous interior. One feels dwarfed when inside..

http://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g298507-d300132-Reviews-St_Isaac_s_Cathedral-St_Petersburg_Northwestern_Dis. Very spectacular, massive with wonderful interior. Great pictures inside of its construction and protection during WWII.
Beautiful Gold Dome Church. This is one of the first churches you see when you come into St. Petersburg. It is very beautiful and on the must see list.

Awe Inspiring. More of a museum than a cathedral although services are held there on major occasions. We were gob smacked by the immensity of it and everything in it. Another centrally located attraction.
Get in the sky. See it inside and then walk up the stairs to colonade to see the city-opposite you will see the teracce restaurant o W hotel,worth to visit as well
A beautiful and meaningful visit.. I loved the mosaics on the walls especially. The architecture was also fantastic.

a must see. If you are going in winter remember that everything closes early as it gets dark early. The inside is just as stunning as the outside. You have to go up on the observation deck we could see the whole city from up there,was breathtaking. Just remember to take some warm clothes as its quite windy up there. Inside the church the ceiling is just magnificently painted, the dome is decorated with twelve statues of angels by Josef Hermann. I stood there quite a while just staring up. The church also has huge bronze doors covered in reliefs that you cannot mis,
Outside & inside quite a contrast. The outside may be somber but the inside of St. Isaac's is lavish. Don't miss this enormous church/museum.
Go!. If you get the chance to climb to the dome don't pass it up! You can see forever from up there. The display that shows how they erected the columns is really cool.

Quirky combination of church/museum/shop. St. Isaac's Cathedral is a quirky kind of place that does not appear to have quite decided whether it is a museum, a church or a shop and so has tried to be all three. There is an entry fee in to the 'museum' which in reality is the entire ground floor of the church. Inside you'll find some stunning ceiling paintings and art but also a strange mismatch of souvenir stall selling religious tat and temporary exhibitions. Worth a visit for the ceilings alone but does get quite busy (we went 11am). You can pay separately to go up to the viewing platform outside for views over the city.
Splendour. one of our most beuatiful Church, to be seen, visit and enjoy the history of such building... just great place - go on top to have a view on St Petersbourg
Breathtaking. Fantastic and beautiful. From outside its lovely but inside its spectaculour. Must see.

Take the steps if you can! Otherwise see the inside!. There was a service going on while visiting which we enjoyed. the magnitude of this beautiful cathedral is one to sit and absorb the wonders of it all. The art work is being made into moasics. look at the detail on the TV's....touch the screen to view.
St Isaac's Cathedral. You cannot describe this lovely cathedral in daily words! You will always remember these wonderful art!

Large and lavishly decorated. The marble columns at the entrance seem larger than those at the Vatican. The inside also seems bigger but it is only 4th largest behind the Vatican's St. Peter Basilica, Florence's Santa Maria, london's St. Paul's. However it is to me the most impressive with gold all over. Malachite was used to coat the columns of the main altar from thousands of pieces. Also blue lapiz lazuli columns painstakingly made to look solid made from thousands of pieces.
impressive. it is another must in St PeterburgAudio guide well done
Very special. Very special building -- and the day we were there was the city anniversary so we were able to experience an actual service with the a capella choir. Must see
St. Isaac's Cathedral. This was a really beautiful church which was very ornate.
a bit disappointing. The interior of this cathedral had no atmosphere - it's more a museum than a cathedral, and we rather regretted the money we paid to get in.

Beautiful interior, and make sure to go up top. The cathedral looks great from the outside, and breathtaking inside. It's a giant open space with nothing in the middle so it has plenty of space for groups to move around and won't feel overwhelmed. All the architectural details are amazing, and everything kind of glows in the dim lighting. The light rays coming in from the center dome was pretty great too. Make sure you go up to the top while you are there. It does suck a little that they charge extra for visiting the roof area but it's worth it. You'll get a 360 view of St. Petersburg with the main canal and the Hermitage on one side and other churches and cathedrals as well as residential areas on the other side. There's no elevator and you'll have to climb 262 steps to the top. But they are shallow steps so it's not too bad. It won't take too long to see the cathedral and go up to the top, so it's definitely worth a visit even if you do not have a lot of time in St. Petersburg.note: there were still constructions when I went, but it wasn't too bad or distracting at all.

Must Visit. This buiilding is beuatiful! Yes, some of the Icons may be getting restored and have copies instead, there might be a lot of workers around, but you have to remember St.Petersburg is over 300 years old. ignore that and enjoy the cathedral. Do purchase a ticket to go up. It's a bit of a hike if you are out of shape (200 and some stairs), but do it!

work of art!. This is a must-see when you in St.Pete. Make sure that you go inside and that you climb up on the top of the colonnade - the view from there is absolutely gorgeous.
You will be amazed by the beauty of the building inside and outside - I guarantee you that!
also great. another great church -- there are just so, so many
Stunning views of the city from the colonnade. Take the trip up to the top and capture stunning views of the city.

Another True look of Russian Construction.... This Russian Orthodox church sits behind the bronze statue of Peter the Great. Can't miss the dome gold plate entrance with a series of angels. There is no presence of religion just a mirror of tons of paintings by Russian artist. Columns, granite and marble makes up this beautiful cathedral. Our tour guide relates that it took over 40 years to remove any religious depictions and reconstruct the present day image. A must see!!
Very beautiful building. But it was also a masterpiece and took several year to build !. On the way to Russian museeum , stop and see the catedral an the way.
nice when they finish renovations. too many workers and scaffeling around to enjoy. many of the icons were not there and just copies in their place.
fabulous. video and camers. So much to see so little time. A dream trip
See St. Isaac and compare with St. Peter. Very impressive work and especially the panoramic city view from the top.

Wonderful view from the top. Good thing to do when you start your visit in St Petersburg is to climb (ab 200 staires) to the top and get a good view of the city. Unfortunately the inside was closed (on wednesdays) so we didn`t see that.
Beautiful. Impressive as the city itself. Only point is takes long time to enter, and a little expensive.
Top sight. It's my favorite place in St.Pete. Don't think too much of inside but it's definately worth visiting the tower if you dont have problems climbing stairs - nice view over City and square.
Extraordinary Church. Christian church with a magnificent building and architecture. A must see monument.
Southern Europe. Note that the French and Italian architects built most of St Pete and this is a great example. If you are expecting Russian architecture here you will not be pleased
Impressive. Stunning decor , awe inspring and great views of St Petersburg

Great views of the city. Words can't describe what the inside of this cathedral looks like. For an extra fee you can follow the winding stairs up to the collonade for some pretty impressive views around this part of Saint Petersburg
Also a must-visit. It's wonderful that St. Isaac's is being restored. We were able to watch some of the meticulous work being done.

Views from on high. A lot of steps to get to the top for which there is an additional fee, well worth it but if you are on the larger side and can make the steps there is a narrow doorway leading to another set of steps after about 200. Well worth it and the only place to get a view from on high.
Impressive. This church is so impressive outside. But it is even more impressive inside.

take the million stairs. The best part is to take the million or so stairs up to the rotunda. The view of STP is very nice from here.
The shops inside sell some very beautiful religious icons. Much better quality than what you find in the outdoor market near the Spilled Blood.

Biggest cathedral in Russia?. Clime up to roof of Isaac Catheral and see 360 agrees of St-Petersburg. about 268 step up but wonderful wiev over city. Museum/Cartherdal is breathtaking and it is clear now why they build it up 40 years. best
jorma

Shiny gold domes. The Church is like a giant that you can spot from very far. They say that the golden and shiny domes were painted dark during WWII to prevent the Germans from identifying the surroundings from the planes.I did not walk inside but the external architecture is worth pictures and attention.In front of it there is an equestrian monument to Nicholas I.

Great 360 views of SPb. Be sure you climb the stairs to see some stunning 360 degree views of the city. The walk up the stairs takes less than five minutes so it’s not too long and definitely worth it. The inside of the cathedral (the museum) is beautiful – mosaics, green and blue pillars, and a nice, if succinct, history of the three churches built over the years named after St Isaac. Definitely worth the stop if you are in the area, especially the climb up the stairs. Nowhere else in SPb has these views.
What a view!. Climb to the top for an amazing view! We went on a very quiet day but I would suggest to visit early if visiting in summer.

Stunning. The cathedral has been beautifully restored. There are lots of interesting displays in English to understand the history of the place. Again you need to pay to enter but well worth the money.
Terrific night view of Saint-Pete. Like Isaac's Cafedral very much. It's very nice to go there at night and catch wonderful views of Saint-Pete center.

St Isaac Cathedral. I am not a Christian and hence the paintings inside the Cathedral is not much of a significance as I am not able to co-relate it to the limited knowledge of Christianity that I know. The interiors of St Isaac Cathedral, St Kazan Cathedral and the Church of our Saviour on Spilled Blood for a layman appears to be the same. There is no entry fee to St. Kazan Cathedral. The Church of our Saviour on Spilled Blood is a must to be seen, inspite of the entrance fees. So one can avoid the interiors of St. Isaac. However there is a separate ticket if one has to climb the 262 steps and go up. This is a lovely spot and one can see and enjoy the scenic beauty of St Petersburg.

You gotta climb to the top. It is a cathedral, so you will find many men and women praying - they may make you take your hat off if you are a man, but will not (and this is puzzling) tell you to cover your hair if you are a woman, as the Orthodox practice requires. Oh well, it's their God...The interior of the Cathedral is quite overwhelming both in colorm, quantity, size and panache. So allocate more time to digest it at a slower pace, otherwise your eyeballs will get overwhelmed - there are paintings on all sides left, down, right, and up.You have to buy a separate ticket and walk around the Cathedral yet again to climb up - but it is SO WORTH IT. You can see the whole of St. Petersburg with narration in Russian telling you what's what...In good clear weather you will be blown away by the grandeur of Peter the Great's design. You had to be a Russian crazy Tsar obsessed with world domination to pick such a swamp for your capital - but it all worked out :)

Must See. This is a StP Must See. Depending on your interests, you can do it in 30 minutes, or longer if you want to go into detail. If you have the legs & stamina, the separate stairs tour to the top of the dome is worth it for the bird's eye view of the city.
Impressive. Very large and imposing from the outside, the Cathedral is spectacular inside.
Beautiful. The Russians certainly liked spending their money on monuments and this one is no exception. Worth a visit.
Main Cathedral. It's one of the three biggest cathedrals in Europe and very beautiful, interesting history of how it was built.
Go to the top.. We walked up the stairs and the view from the top was worth the effort.

Inside beautiful, on top fantastic. In the freezing Russian winter ( -15C and strong winds) we climbed the three hundred stairs to the collonade to get the amazing 360 degree view over the city. Breathtaking!

beauty unfolded. Lovely, atmospheric and from an era of untold decadence and lavishness seldom seen in the empire elsewhere. A beautiful building, well maintained/restored with gorgeous colours and worthy of a couple of hours if you take time to sit and take all in around you
Charming view. Take the 200 steps up the inside to the dome and walk around it to see the whole of St Petersburg.

It's great both inside, outside and upside.. St. Isaac's CAthedral is one three cathedrals with such a dome in the world (other two are St. Peter's Cathedral in Vatican and St. Paul's Cathedral in London).You can climb up and see the great panoramic view on the city, or you can visit the inside of the cathedral (it's stiil working as a church) and see the masterpieces of ortodox arts. Or you can just walk around the building, which still has the marks of World War II.

An Excellent Cathedral. We visited St Isaac's on a cold winters afternoon and thought we'd made a mistake- how wrong can you be. It's a brilliant building with lots of things of interest to see. We also went up to the dome- a super view across the whole area but obviously choose a clear day and wear something (very) warm if visiting in the winter.

Remarkable!. The trip to the top of the colonnade is a must as it gives you 360 degree views of the city. You must buy both tickets at the ticket booth on the other side of the cathedral to the actual entrance.
Nice. Well, another great site, imagine that it survived the communist regime, visit it
Impressive monument. Another spectacular church for its paintings and architecture

Impressive by any measure. I have traveled extensively, and I am definitely a cynic when it comes to seeing (yet more) churches, but I was blown away by St. Isaac's Cathedral. It is remarkably compact yet very open, and the views in all directions from any spot within the cathedral are inspiring. It is an easy walk as a side visit (even in the deep cold of February) if you're heading to the Hermitage. It is also the kind of place you could spend hours noting the intricate craftsmanship and artwork, but you can also enjoy in less than an hour if you're pressed for time.If you're in St Petersburg, St Isaac's Cathedral is definitely worth a visit.

Pretty church but the views from the top are brilliant. Definitely go to the top of this cathedral - the views are lovely for a 360 degree view of St. Petersburg. Quite cheap to climb to the top - well worth it.
ST Petersburg is Wonderfull. The attractions are all the very finest you will ever see in your life
Beautiful building. Lovely building well worth visiting and easy to find.

Climb the tower!. Worth buying both the cathedral and tower ticket BUT you need a head for heights, narrow spiral staircases and the ability to climb 256 steps! Worth the view though from the top, and worth doing to see Health & Safety Russian style as the workmen hang from delisting the roof!
Beautiful inside and out. Didn't manage to go up onto the colonade - would like to do that next time (!) but inside is lovely anyway
Luxurious internal decorations. The church is very big, it can contain up to 12000 people (my guide says so). you can see a dove in the middle of the central cupola. Full of gold and marbol.

Beautiful. Beautiful example of assymetry of onion domes and color. Note, there is a fee to enter the cathedral. Art lovers and historians will be quite impressed; otherwise, there are other cathedrals to visit for a small donation.

Beautiful. It is at the moment the forth largest domed cathedral in Europe after St.Paul's in London, St.Peter's in Rome, and Santa Maria del Fiore in Florence. If you go to St.Petersburg in summer I would also recommend to save some strength to mount over 300 steps to reach the 270-foot/90m high observation platform of the Colonnade where you can get a picturesque view of the city.
Very nice cathedral. We walked up to the collonade for a great view. It was freezing and there was renovation work and structures around, but worth the trip neverthless.
Excellent. I had an excellent private guide, who really made this place come alive. It is enormous and full of history.
Very impressive. It was very impressive cathedral. It was stunning landmark with great view of St. Pete on top! one point deducted for the security as I was pickpocketed in the crowd!
Nice model of the church. I liked the wooden model of the church construction best. I did not climb to the roof, but otherwise the church did not look exceptional to em.
city's overview. it is very imporant to go upstairs and to see the city from the top of the cathedral. There is no other choice to do it!
Beautiful.. Worth a look at not expensive to get in. ONLY 250r.
worth it for the view. it cost 150 roubles to climb the steps to the top and see the city from above. we saw a striking blue domed building from here which we decided to go and see.
Just magnificent!. Beautiful inside and has a great view from it's top. Loved it!

WOW!!!. This is an incredible sight. We did not have much time in St. Petersburg but this was the first place we visited. Absolutely incredible! The wealth of the tsarist regime is certainly in evidence here, it is a dazzling gem.

Stupendous. The scale and opulence of the cathedral is breathtaking. One of the great churches of the world, with a far less austere feel than the Gothic minsters. Perhaps most like St Peter's but whereas that appears designed to intimidate, St Isaacs simply inspires amazement.
Beatiful Church. impressive colunata, beatiful golden dome, worth the visit

Dizzying heights. We climbed the spiral staircase to the very top for panoramic views of the city, however, the last flight of stairs are out in the open and i don't like heights so felt a little queasy

Beautiful Space. It was very breathtaking. My wife loves iconography and she really enjoyed all the wonderful icons on display. It is also centrally located so you cannot miss it! Definitely worth a visit. I will say though that it is not meticulously arranged as say in the Smolniy.

Breath taking. The panoramic views from the top is more than great.
The inside is excellant. Drawings, walls cieling, statues... Waw

The View From the Colonnade Is So Majestic. I loved its colonnade,even though the weather was quite cold and wet when I explored around it.Great views of the Hermitage,Peter and Paul Fortress,Church of Spilled Blood.I enjoyed the interior of this devotional art museum also,espeicially its iconstasis and works by painters T.Neff and Bruni I also learned interesting things about Saint Isaac.
Very impressive Cathedral.. Impressive, but I preferred the Church of Our Savior on Spilled Blood.
Unique history. This church has colorful history, which you need to know before you can really understand this place. Boring is, that locals have to pay less than tourists to go in.
Massive cathedral. A must visit in St Petersburg. Very central and imposing location. The massive cost in building has meant this place has stood the test of time.
Best view in town!. The climb to the top of the dome made my legs a little shaky but well worth it for the view. We were spoilt with a sunny clear day, and you can see for miles around
Magnificent. We visited the Cathedral on a cold, but clear day. We also saw it all lightened up late in the evening.
go to the top!. The inside is beautiful but the real fun is going up the 200 steps to the top of the cathedral. From there you have an awesome view of all of Peter.

Amazing! And big!. think about something big! Yeah, it´s bigger than what you have thought! It´s so beautiful! But let me tell you: boys just in pants, girls in pants or skirt. Or they won´t let you go in...
Massive. A Cathedral that is exceptional, from the marble colums outside to the amazing interior, just awe inspiring,

Best view of the city. Go up the colanade its about 240 + steps and you will get a fantastic view of the city. Try go around sun set. It is chilly up there though to wrap up! Also inside the cathedral are some stunning frescos and an interactive tool to learning about the builing of the cathedral. This was my favourite site on our whole visit!
A must-see while you're in St. Pete. There are few things like Hermitage and Neva boat trip and of course St. Isaac's Cathedral that you have to do in Petersburg!

stunning construction and great views. Built in just over 40 years this is an impressive piece of archintecture. I love the model in the cathedral that shows the erection of the massive pillars. A spare one seems to have found its way to the Hermitage square

Beautiful, Informative Sightseeing Experience. Our tour visited around 4 p.m. so there were no crowds to jostle us while we looked at the cathedral and several very informative displays. Many churches, cathedrals, etc. offer poor to zero informative information, displays, etc. St. Issac's offered a beautiful, insightful visit

Beautiful church, climb the stairs. Just going to a different style church that is so immence makes St. Isaacs a top church to visit. The dome is lovely with its story and the peace dove in the center. Be sure to climb the steps for a fantastic view of the city
Well worth visiting. This is the largest cathedral in Russia and definitely worth visiting. The works of art are amazing.

St. Peters view from the Colonade is spetacular. You will have to go up some 200+ steps.. but once you get up to the colonade level, you will be amazed by the mos spetacular views of St. Petersburg! Tickets are charged just for the church or for the church and colonade. I got tickets for both and am glad I did that. It is not a huge church, but it is very, very beautiful! The colonade has a 360 degrees view of the city! Just beautiful!!
Nice site on the way to work. I "had" to walk past St isaac on the way to the office. An amazing site. It's well worth it to climb the stairs to the top to have look over St Pete's roof tops.

most luxurious Baroque church in the world. St Isaak's cathedral is ranked the 4th largest cathedral in the world,after the Basilica ofSt Paul (Vatican),St Paul's Cathedral (London) and the cathedral of Seville (Spain).I visited them all and the only comparable and rival for first place is the Basilica St Paulin Vatican. I didn't say which is the most beautiful church of all,because Europe hasseveral top-beauty of the baroque churches : Gesu (Jesus),St Ignace of Loyola,Santa Maria Maggiore,San Giovanni in Laterano (papal residence,prior to the Vatican) - all of them in Rome (Italy) - or the church of Melk monastery (Austria). The most beautiful interior of churches is in Baroque style and the most beautiful church exterior in the world belongs to the Dome of Florence (Italy). I visited all the churches above,I've got photos and albums about them,so that I can make a comparison in this matter.If I am to compare St Isaak Cathedral with another one,I would compare it only withSt Paul's Basilica in Vatican,where dominate the Carrara white marble and the gildeddecorations,including the dome; we can add here colored marbles (green,black,brown,red) of the pavement and of some sumptuous tombs of pops,as well as Bernini'ssplendid canopy placed above the grave site of St Peter. Overall,a breathtaking beauty !I don't say which cathedral is the most beautiful.I only say that St Isaak Cathedral in St Petersburg (Russia) is the most LUXURIOUSBaroque church in the world,because it has not only marbles (white and colored) andgold, but also semi-precious stones (malachite,lazurite) ,superb stained glass windowsand superb gold plated statues. BREATHTAKING, by BEAUTY and LUXURY !This is what I saw and felt in St Isaak Cathedral, St Petersburg. I join several photos taken in place,so everyone can judge for himself.Too bad it was too dark inside the church and the splendors were not emphasized asthey fully deserve !

On a Clear Day....the 360 views of one magnificent City. Only visit the Rotunda (211 steps) on a clear day or you will be disappointed in the view. There is a 365 view of the city of St. Petersburg which is awesome. The interior of the Cathedral is breathtaking. Do not pay extra to take pictures. There is no monitor it is an honor system...let you conscience be your guide.

Magnificent construction.. Visit was in August 2010 Was fscinated by the method of construction and placment of the huge colonnades.the view of the city was great including the Astoria Hotel. The upper iron stairway is a distraction from the frontal view of the cathedral.

Impressive.. I have seen many orthodox cathedrals of various traditions over the years and there have been many where I have felt more reverence however this is by any stretch of the imagination an impressive building. It was explained to us that the cathedral was built to hold thousands of worshippers and the acoustics, if you can get a little quiet, are great. The columns by the icon screen, lapis lazuli and malachite are wondrous. It's almost impossible to believe you could find that much lapis! The exhibitions and mosaic displays are also well worth seeing and do check out the bullet damage on the columns on the outside of the massive carved doors. It was only a pity that we did not get a chance the day I was there to climb to the top.

A Splendid cathedral. I appreciated that cathedral so much. Despites long queues , really worths a while. The iconostasys is really splendid .I could spend hours there admiring all the details. The most gripping was the coluns at the right side when you enter: Malachite from Ural mountains and Lapis lazuli from Afganistan (take a look at my photos) After visiting i climbed literally until the observation deck just below the golden dome and could enjoy a stunning view of all St Petersburg. But this part will require a good health condition from you because there are no elevators , just stairs..

Probably too pricey. For a price of 250 roubles which doesn't include the colonnade is probably too pricey for me. However, the museum/church inside itself is very beautiful. For the same price or if they add 50 roubles more but allow us to climb up the colonnade would be great. Still worth a visit though.

Huge cathedral, impressive interior, not to be missed!. Grand cathedral with highly ornate interiors, the bronze doors are covered with reliefs so fascinating one could spend hours studying them, each tells a story! Many of the paintings decorating the interior had also been reproduced in mosiac of AMAZING finesse. Do not miss the colonnade (tkts have to be separately purchased) for it offers a birds eye view of the city. Regret not going up at night (I visited in summer), think the lights would be beautiful! Do get the audioguide for more insights on the construction and history. :)

Its Size is Its Most Remarkable Attribute. Many official St. Petersburg tourism photos showcase this icon. In addition to its beauty, it earns bonus points for sheer size. I loved the malachite and lapis columns inside the building. We didn’t go up to the colonnade (an extra charge, naturally). You might visit the bar at the top of the W Hotel for a very similar city view without the lines.

Impressive church, with great views. I hadn't realized just how big St. Isaacs really is, until we walked up to the church. It's nearly impossible to actually view it from up close (and it is hemmed in on three sides by roads and buildings) and even crossing to the small park to try to get a photo only emphasizes the size of this absolutely enormous church. The huge porticos with heavy columns are impressive, and give the church a very heavy, solid look. No soaring gables here, no light-as-air windows. This feels more like a huge mausoleum plopped down into the center of town, topped by a gleaming gold dome that is visible above the surrounding buildings.Tickets to go inside to view the church (and the various exhibits inside, it is more museum than church) and to climb up the colonnade for views out over the city are sold separately. It is definitely worth the haul up the 265 stairs to the gallery around the colonnade (I was disappointed that you don't actually get to go up the final spiral staircase to the very top of the dome, but that's not permitted), with great views over the city, especially on a sunny day. Nearly every other landmark is visible. The spiral staircase is quite wide and easy to maneuver for most of the way, then narrows down as you reach the last few turns (with a good railing). The last bit of the climb is an external straight stair up to the colonnade, quite a relief from all the circling. There are two staircases, one for up and one for down, so you aren't trying to pass anyone on the stairs. There is no time limit on climbing up, or just sitting up on the colonnade to enjoy the view.Inside, the decorated dome and arches are beautiful, and the sheer size of the place is a bit more obvious. There are various displays of icons nad paintings, and models of the domes and church to peer at, but most of the time is spent staring up at the ornate walls and dome. It's quite different from the shining interior of Church on the Spilled Blood, or the inside of the Kazan Cathedral, but it is impressive to look up into the huge dome and soaring arches, and to see the hugely thick doors (almost like vault doors) leading in to the church. Not a huge amount of gold leaf in here.The colonnade and church are open quite late (even later in summer), but the ticket kiosk moves to the other side of the building, so you have walk around to get in. Easy, but our first visit, we didn't realize that the church was still open, since we didn't see the location of the "night" ticket window.Climb up for the view, but don't miss seeing the inside of this enormous building, either. Perhaps it's not the "traditional" church interior, but don't miss it.

An imposing landmark, even by St. Petersburg standards.. Note: The cathedral/museum part of this church is closed on Wednesday, which just so happened to be the day we went. So plan accordingly, if your interested in going inside. This is one of the largest buildings in St. Petersburg, and that's saying a lot. Its huge golden dome and massive structure not only makes a great reference point, but the grand scale and historical significance of this church makes for an interesting visit. Due to us going on the day the inside was closed, we could only go up to its observation colonnade, which in itself was worth the price (80R if I remember correctly). The commanding view of the city from this point really gives you an appreciation for how big St. Petersburg is, not to mention a view of other distant sites and the river Neva. We went on a day that was quite warm, so the breeze up there was also very refreshing. Note: The stairwell leading up to the observation colonnade is long, somewhat narrow, winding and at times poorly lit so use good judgement if planning to go up. The good part was when we went, the inner stairwell was still very cool inside.

Imposing golden dome - viewable from much of the city. St. Isaac's cathedral is an imposing building with a shiny golden dome that can be viewed from much of central St. Petersburg. We used it as a point of reference for identifying where we were on the maps many times during our trip to St. Petersburg. From the outside, the cathedral appears tired and old, neoclassical pillars and structure. The inside was ok, nothing as nice as Church of our Lady on Spilled Blood and offered little in the form of good photo taking. If you are in St. Petersburg for enough time, then we recommend a stop here, but if you've very limited time, go to Church of our Lady of Spilled Blood instead. It was much more beautiful on the inside and outside.

Sacriligeous comments. I would like just 2 sacriligeous details: one relatively new and one already missing.So, what is missing? The pendulum of Fuko, which had been here since 1930ies, a period of antireligious strife, till 1989. it was a popular trick: a pendulum with a very long thread (almost 100 m) due to influence of the earth rotation changes visibly direction of swinging. I remember my astonishment some 45 years ago. Then, looking ironically, in 1989 they have decided to abolish this proof of the rotation (either thinking that it is obvious - or abolishing rotation in general) with the original silver dove, the symbol of the Holy Ghost. Here we can also remember about another ghost, Marx's Ghost of Communism from his famous manifesto. Then, probably that pendulum was an embodiement of the Ghost of communism?One recent addition reminds about the New testament episode with Christ driving moneylenders out of the Temple. Nowadays they have managed to make their way back to St.Isaac's: by the exit you will find an ITM machine...

Saint Isaac's Cathedral Russia St. Petersburg. One of most beautiful Russian church, one of main symbol of Saint Petersburg. It's place near from the backing River Neva in historical center of St Petersburg. You will see a fine paint's and dome with beautiful fresco with biblical subject. All wall's paints also fresco, gold and bronze stucco work. When You come to lofty point of building you arrive to observation area with lovely see to St Petersburg. When you tide you can go to jazz - club Gravizapa with nice and talented musician and good kitchen.
beautiful on the outside; not worth the cost to go inside. After Church on Spilled Blood, the interior of St. Isaac's was "just another nice church."

Don't miss it if you come to St Petersburg. St Isaac 's is definitely one of the must-see sights in St Petersburg. You might think that you've been to so many cathedrals in different countries that you can do very well without another one , but that ' s where you are wrong . Outside, it might be as impressive as some other big cathedrals , but inside, it beats a good many of them.The cathedral used to be Russia ' s major Orthodox church in the 19th century. The interior walls are faced with 14 kinds of different- colored marble and decorated with numerous paintings, murals , and mosaics by Russia ' s eminent 19th -century artists. The iconostasis with golden mosaic icons and huge columns of bright- green malachite and bright -blue lapis lazuly is really stunning , so make sure you bring your camera to take some gorgeous pictures of the inside.The booking -office is right next to the entrance : An adult ticket is 320 rubles (about USD 10) and no credit cards accepted - it has to be cash, and Russian rubles only. To take pictures of the inside , you have to book a camera permit inside the cathedral (50 rubles - about USD 1.70) .Besides seeing the inside, you can climb up to the observation platform at the top of the colonnade to get the best panoramic view of St Petersburg and its main river , the Neva. You will need to book a separate ticket to go up (worth 100 rubles - about USD 3), but think twice before you decide to do it: There is no elevator , which means you will have to spend quite a while climbing up the 300 steps of the spiral stairway inside the thick wall. If you have done this in St Paul ' s in London, then you have a pretty good idea of what the climb in St Isaac 's is like. When you do get to the top , however , you are rewarded with a magnificent view of the city 's historical center.

Awesome _ Inside, Outside and on Top...!!. St Isaac's is located on a prominent square rubbing shoulders with the Astoria (which sports a menu handwritten and ordered by the Fuhrer to commomerate capture of St Petersburg, an event which never happened) and Blue Bridge (the widest of the hundreds of bridges in St Petersburg). The tall dark granite columns and the magnificent dome of this almost 200 yrs old, and the largest of St Petersburg's cathedrals, are reminiscent of St Paul's, London and St Peter's Basilica, Vatican and are no less impressive. The huge bronze doors hide an awe inspiring interior - the insides host a wealth of Orthodox Russian Icons, murals and paintings, the sight of which more than compensates for the large entrance fee. The icon of Tikhvin is especially considered as healing and wonder-working. A suspended dove is seen from inside below the dome and is said to depict the Holy Spirit. A visit to this museum complex isnt complete without climbing up onto the top of the collanades - this offers an all round view of the great city from almost 100 metres height. This square is perhaps the only one in this city to have been spared the Nazi bombing and what you see is very much the original from the outside.

Lovely church. This church has seen some changes! Af one point it even housed an anti religious museum. Now it has been restored to being a church, but without worshippers, so is called a museum. At the ticket office we were a little confused between "museum" and "collonade" if you want to go in the church its the museum price and the collonade is to go up to the dome fore view. We didn't do the collonade, but we did go inside the church and it was pretty spectacular. It has lapis lazuli and malachite columns at one end with plenty of mosaics as well. There are displays on the changes to the church since it was built, which are interesting to look at as well. It was well worth the visit!

Beautiful View. An absolutely lovely Cathedral with the best views of St. Petersburg anywhere.Well worth seeing if it Petersburg along with the Herimitage (absoutely amazing -- could spend over a week and not see everything) and the Peter and Paul fortress.

Best church in Russia, bar none.. No question the best church we went to in Russia. Worth the admission price and more. I would say you can spend from 2 to 5 hours here without getting bored. Great mosaic art all around.
